abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Sustainable Management
            of Mineral Resources Project for Uganda were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately satisfactory; risk to development
            outcome was substantial; Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory; and borrower performance was also moderately
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned includes: realistic
            estimation of project costs and financing requirements to
            avoid implementation delays. Government commitment to
            budgeting sufficient funds to cover recurrent cost in order
            to sustain project investments beyond the project closing
            date; flexible and close donor coordination and
            collaboration; the importance of supporting gender
            mainstreaming in the mining sector, especially in Artisanal
            and small-scale mining (ASM), which requires gaining the
            trust of local governments as well as communities. The
            project accomplished this through extensive, participatory
            consultations and trainings; and the merit of 'peer
            support,' such as brining in a former project
            coordinator of a World Bank project from Romania; as well as
            the necessity to approach mining sector development from
            different interrelated angles, such as looking to reform, in
            parallel, the mining sector's regulatory framework and
            institutional set up; capacity building of the lead agency
            to improve governance; increase transparency through
            computerization of the mining cadastre; promote the mineral
            sector through high quality data and integrated data
            management; and to redress adverse environmental, social and
            economic conditions typically associated with informal
            mining by incentivizing the legalization of and giving a
            'leg up out of poverty' to small scale miners.
